I'm glad that this study on puppies could help breed better dogs for service but, I also kind of fear the information could also be used to promote the idea that Prue breeds are smarter than mutts. This isn't always the case and people use this reasoning to not adopt from shelters. Also many breeders don't allow for enough genetic diversity and the dogs have health problems. I have a Prue bred German Shepherd who more often than not is missing huge chunks of hair because he is allergic to everything. We recently got him allergy tested again and have added grass, yes grass, to the long list. We have to buy special dog food for him because he is allergic to a lot of ingredients. We have to give him medication regularly to help with the arthritis in his hips . He is ageing poorly considering he is seven and my mom had a lab mutt of about the same size and he lived to be eighteen and was healthy as a horse till a week before his death. I really hope this study doesn't go to furthering breeding more dog with health problems. It's hard to see your dog suffer and I know some breeders will put down unhealthy pups who have it worse than my dog.

I have an auditory processing disorder and I find I accidentally interrupt people or think someone else has interrupted me when they haven't all the time. It is especially frustrating if I'm really tired, it's near impossible to have a conversation with me without me getting upset because, I can't get my words out.  I wonder what could even be done if scientist find out exactly how to fix that part of the brain in people like me that would even help considering I don't think anyone would find brain surgery worth it unless the problem was severe. That without even considering the cost of medical bills. At least with video calls we will eventually be able to achieve pretty smooth connections, we already have pretty good ones already that should keep that from being too much of a hiderance.
Dogs are better than cats. Deal w/ it.

I have some concerns about the validity of this puppy study, namely bias in the manner in which every puppy was introduced to the task, and the condition each puppy was kept in before put to task. Environmental and social factors may have had a factor in the puppy's responses, as well as specific tone, speed of gesture, and whether or not the puppy was paying attention to specific things in its surroundings.

Mistake - wolves were not domesticated by man. Wolves and dogs share a common ancestor, but dogs did not come from wolves. All dogs also have a common ancestor that they do not share with wolves. It appears that dogs and wolves split before and without human intervention. This is what the most current genetic and archeological evidence shows us.
See work of Genomics researcher Anders Bergstrom

2:34 nope; using a group of bred for human interaction of this kind to study (these are assistance dogs and have been bred, singularly, for this use for over 50 years, meaning generation after generation of pups is selected out for this ability) and then coming to the conclusion that all dogs have this ability is unsound science. Not a wrong conclusion, but false using this group of puppies to correlate to the wider group of dogs overall.
Yes, dogs have been selected out for face contact, gestures, and vocal understanding, however, using a specially bred population within the larger group skews your results. Just saying.

I'm all about researching the canine genome to help with some of the inheritable disorders out there.

Here's why:

Atypical Addison's Disease
Somewhere around April or March I see a post on a group I set up for my pup and his bio siblings that were all adopted from the same rescue. They are the muttiest mutts that ever did mutt. Seriously, you look at any one of them and there are only vague hints at what breeds they're made up of. We thought maybe we'd be able to tell when they got older but nope. Almost two years old and people see everything from Lab to Aussie Shep to a bully breed. Even the different doggie DNA testing companies are spitting out different results. (That's for an entirely different reason, though.)

But back to the post, it was from one of the other doggos mom's letting us all know that their pup had been diagnosed with Atypical Addison's Disease aka The Great Pretender. This jerk of a disease has so many seemingly mundane symptoms that oftentimes nobody knows that there's a deeper issue going on.

So the scramble to get all the pups tested begins, because this thing can kill, quickly. (The speed of it honestly reminds me a bit of Parvo even though this is actually an auto immune disorder.)

And then one of our worst fears was realized. A few days after being diagnosed and the day he had his first treatment, one of the dogs just died. There was no warning. He was with his moms and doggie sister and he just died.

At this point none of the other dogs have been positively diagnosed for Atypical Addison's, but they all have markers for it.

It's like being in a constant game of waiting, and will they or won't they, and if so, when?

Right now there are a number of studies going on for Atypical Addison's but as far as I can see they all deal with pure bred dogs. And while that's important to get a baseline because, as is pointed out in the video, the parentage is known, I think it's time that some branching out is done.

tl;dr I'm all about the exploration of the canine genome because I really don't want my dog or any more of his bio siblings to die.

I was so busy thinking about puppies that I have no idea what the second part of the video was about.

The squirrels in my back yard will go where I point to get the peanuts I leave for them.  You can definitely tell different squirrel individuals have different levels of understanding.  Many are dumb as a rock, but some are pretty bright.   I'll set up challenges for them to get the nut and they figure it out.  It is pretty amazing with such a tiny brain.

You do realize that dogs are domesticated wolves. A wolf has 30% larger brain than the same sized dog and that's because the dog doesn't need to think for itself for survival. It just needs to follow the leader. And don't get me wrong. I've nothing against dogs. But I do object to humans creating them for their own convenience. When I see dogs acting like this, it makes me cry. Is it not enough that we destroy the Earth? Did we have to bend the evolution to our will as well!?
